module.p:
sàs is an abstract, masculine simple common noun, with genitive singular form sàis. There appear to be two main dictionary senses –
a state of being caught, trapped or captured
[by metaphorical extension] a state of being busy at, engaged or involved in something cf. Old Gaelic sás snare, trap (for birds).
In modern Gaelic, the noun sàs is always used in the idiom an sàs (an ...) denoting the property of being in such a state.

Examples without a complement –
concrete –
Tha iad an sàs.
They are in captivity. td. 319
[...] far a bheil na fèithean-lùthaidh an sàs [...]
[...] where the sinews are fixed [...] td. 502
abstract –
Tha deichnear an sàs làn-aimsireach.
There are ten people engaged full time. td. 502

bi an sàs an –
concrete –
Bha am ball an sàs anns a’ chraoibh.
The ball was stuck in the tree. td. 502
abstract –
Bha mi an sàs anns an obair seo fad iomadh bliadhna.
I was engaged in this work for many years. td. 502
Tha làn sgioba de sgrìobhadairean an sàs an tionndadh a-mach nam prògraman.
There’s a full team of writers engaged in turning out the programmes. td. 502
’S e adhbhar an Tighearna anns a bheil mi an sàs.
It’s the Lord’s Work in which I am engaged. td. 502–3
[...] a bharrachd air a bhith an sàs ann an obair a’ mhisein [...]
[...] as well as being engaged in the work of the mission [...] td. 503
Bha e an sàs ann am mòran ghnothaichean ionadail.
He was engaged in many local matters. td. 503
Bha mi an sàs ann am poileataics aig an àm sin.
I was involved in politics at that time. td. 319

Adnominal examples where the bi is implicit –
radan an sàs ann an ribe
a rat caught in a trap td. 319

bi an sàs ann an cuideigin –
Bha iad an sàs innte gun sgur.
They pestered her continually. td. 502
Bha i an sàs annam fad na h-ùine airson an taigh a pheantadh.
She was on at me all the time to paint the house. td. 319
Tha iad an sàs annam gun sgur.
They’re always on at me. td. 334

Examples –
concrete –
Chaidh i an sàs sna drisean.
She got caught in the brambles. td. 319
abstract –
Bha e ag innleachdadh mar a bha e a’ dol a dhol an sàs ann.
He was planning how he was going to tackle it. td. 502
Bidh cuid a’ dol an sàs san Laidinn.
Some will be taking on Latin. td. 502
ambiguous –
[...] nuair a thèid sibhse an sàs ann [...]
[...] when you tangle with him [...] td. 502

Examples without a complement –
concrete –
Chuir oifigich an airm an sàs e.
The army officers arrested him. td. 502
abstract –
[...] A nis, tha an Taghadh Nàiseanta seachad, agus tha Riaghaltas ùr againn. Tha sinn an dòchas gun téid gu math dhaibh, agus gun cuir iad spionnadh ás ùr anns an dùthaich air fad. Agus gu seachd àraidh anns a’ Ghaidhealtachd: gun tòisich obair an dealain a rithist, gun cuirear tuilleadh bhàtaichean-iasgaich an sàs, gum faigh na Gaidheil cothrom air fearann na Gaidhealtachd obrachadh dhaibh fhéin, ás bith an ann mar chroitean no mar innis no mar choille, gun bhacadh o bhàllidh no o thighearna. [...]
[...] Now, the General Election is behind us, and we have a new Government. We hope that they will do well, and that they will re-energise the whole country. And most especially in the Highlands: that electricity work will restart, that more fishing boats will be put into service [?], that the Gaels will get the opportunity to work the land of the Highlands for themselves, whether as crofts or as grazing or as forest, without hindrance from a bailiff or from a laird. [...] td. 9, ‘Air an Spiris’
air a chuir an sàs
in commission td. 502

cuir an sàs an ... –
[...] ’Se glé bheag de chobhair a thug a’ Phàrlamaid a riamh do ’n Ghàidhlig no do fhoghlum agus do litreachas na Gàidhlig. [...] Dé na rudan a dh’ fhaodadh sinn iarraidh? Tuilleadh de luchd-teagaisg ’s de luchd-ceasnachaidh Gàidhlig. Airgead gu leabhraichean uallachadh is a chlo-bhualadh. Barrachd tìde air an réidio agus air telebhisean. Dithis dhaoine a chur an sàs anns na làmh-sgrìobhainnean Gàidhlig san Leabharlann Nàiseanta, agus dithis eile san Ordnance Survey. [...]
[...] The Parliament has given very little assistance ever to the Gaelic language or to Gaelic education and literature. [...] What are the things that we could demand? More Gaelic teachers and inspectors. Money to prepare and print books. More time on the radio and on television. Involving two people in the Gaelic manuscripts in the National Library, and two others in the Ordnance Survey. [...] td. 9, ‘Air an Spiris’
Chuir e dithis eile an sàs anns an innleachd a bh’ann.
He entangled/involved two others in the plot. td. 502

cuir an sàs ann a bhith ag ... –
Tha An Comunn Gaidhealach a’ bruidhinn air Seanaileir ùr a thaghadh a bhios os cionn obair a’ Chomuinn. [...] Bhiodh a leòr aige ri dhèanamh an toiseach ag ath-nuadhachadh dreach a’ Chomuinn. Tha móran ri dhèanamh ris a’ Mhòd mus beir e air linn an telebhisean, no eadhon air linn an réidio: bu mhath gun cuirte luchd-sgrìobhaidh is luchd-ciùil an sàs ann a bhith a’ cruthachadh ás ùr, an àite bhith an còmhnaidh a’ cur seòrsa de dhreach ùr air seann rudan [...]
The Highland Society is talking about choosing a new General who will oversee the Society’s work. [...] He would have enough to do initially reforming the Society. There is much to do at the Mod before it catches up with ?? the era of television, or even with the era of radio: writers and musicians should be involved in creating afresh, instead of always putting a sort of new form on old things [...] td. 105, ‘Air an Spiris’
